quote: ... the Defiant searched the area    for almost six hours, but we    couldn't find any sign of survivors.
The Cortez was a fine ship.
You knew Captain Swofford a long time.
I introduced him to his wife.
Patrolling the Cardassian border    is getting more and more    dangerous. You never know    when you're going to run into a    squadron of Jem'Hadar fighters.
I guess we popped the champagne    corks too soon.
Everyone thought the war was over    when we retook the station and    pushed the Dominion back into    Cardassian space.
I never believed that... and neither    did you.
A lot of good that did the four    hundred people on the Cortez.
Mister Sisko. So, how do you like    our station so far?
It certainly is big.
I heard about Quentin Swofford.    I'm sorry.
Look, Dad... I know I haven't been    very good company the last few days.
I didn't come here to be entertained.    I came to see you and Jake.
You picked an interesting time to    take your first trip away from Earth.

Well, I figured it was now or    never. Besides, I've been worried    about you. Last couple of times    we've talked... it seemed like the    weight of the entire Alpha    Quadrant was on your shoulders.
Sometimes it feels that way.
Dad... I'm not sure...
Just say it, son.
I just don't know how many friends    I can lose. Every time I think    I've achieved a real victory...    something like this happens and it    all turns to ashes.
So what do you want to do?
Maybe it's time for me to step    down... let someone else make the    tough calls.

I see.        Well, no one's indispensable, son.    Not even you.        Whatever decision you make, I'll    support it.        Of course, if Quentin Swofford was    here... I'd bet he'd have a few    things to say to you.
But he's not here... is he?   That's the whole point.
I'd say you have some thinking to    do... and I've got a dinner date    with my grandson, so I'll let you    get to it.
Who was that?
Where'd he go?
Who?
The man who just walked by my door.
I didn't see anyone.
I could've sworn...
I don't know what you're so    worried about, Ben. I'm not    taking my ship anywhere near the    Cardassian border.
I realize that. But the Dominion    is getting bolder and bolder...    and your freighter is no match for    a Jem'Hadar attack ship.
They'd have to catch me first.
You're really not worried, are you?
Me? I'm fearless. You know    that -- that's why you love me.
I think I follow that logic.
Hey, Benny. See the game last    night?
What?
Ben?
Who was that?
Who was who?
Ben -- where are you going?
Ben -- what's wrong? Are you hurt?
He's awake.        Ben, are you all right?
I think so...
Thank God.
Hey, Dad. You scared us there for    a minute.
What happened?
I'm not sure. I'm reading some    unusual synaptic potentials.        The neural patterns are similar    to those you experienced last year.
You mean when I was having    those... visions about Bajor?
Visions? Does this have something    to do with those Prophets you're    always telling me about?
Could be.
He's not going to need surgery    again, is he?
I don't know yet.         But I'd like you to remain    overnight for observation.
Are you sure that's necessary?
Absolutely. Take a look at these    readings --
You gonna buy that or not?
Personally, I don't see the    attraction. Spaceships, flying    saucers, men from Mars...
What's wrong with men from Mars?

Nothing, except it's all make-   believe. Me -- I like war stories.    Did you see From Here to    Eternity? Burt Lancaster standing    there, in the middle of Pearl    Harbor... machine gun blazing...
(making the sound of     gunfire)   ... shooting down those zeros. If    it had been flying saucers...    forget about it.        So you gonna buy that or not?
Benny.
Hello, Albert.
I thought... that is if you're on    the way to the office...
... we could walk there together?
Exactly.
Ah, there they are.
Voila. A pitcher of plain water    instantly becomes a pitcher of ice    tea.
Incredible.
White Rose Redi-Tea. What an    appalling concept.
I bet H. G. Wells would've liked    it.
I doubt that. No self-respecting    Englishman would.
Pabst!
Pabst! Get out here.
What's wrong now, Herb?
I'll give you one guess.
The battle of the doughnuts, round    twenty-eight.
That's what you called me out here    for -- to complain about the    doughnuts?
They're stale again.
Delicious.
Delicious my eye -- these are two    days old and you know it.
I've been eating doughnuts my    whole life and these weren't baked    more than --        -- six hours ago.
That's it, I quit. I'm going over    to Galaxy.
That rag?
I bet that rag knows the    difference between a doughnut and    a doorstop.
You want to write     Galaxy, go ahead. But  Who's winning? they're not going to pay you four cents a word for   KAY your stories.    A draw... same as always.
(looking for his You're paying him four   matches again) cents a word?    Did you see where I put...
You're paying him four   matches again) cents a word?    Did you see where I put...
Stay out of this, Julius.  ... the matches? I gave       them to you.
If he's getting four, Kay    and I should at least get  Then they should be three.     here...
For that fantasy crap you   (re: Benny's write? You're lucky to    magazine) be getting two.    What's that?
The latest Galaxy. I beg your pardon.
Hey. Benny has the new issue of   "Galaxy".
Heinlein, Bradbury, Sturgeon...    quite a lineup. Add Herbert    Rossoff and it's complete.
What if I promise you fresh    doughnuts tomorrow?
Why should I believe you?
I'll even throw in a couple of    crullers.
Okay, I'll stay.
Don't do us any favors.
All right, now that we've taken    care of the old business...
... onto the new. Time to hand out    next month's story assignments.        Ritterhouse! We're waiting.
Coming.
All right, friends and neighbors,    let's see what Uncle Roy brought    you today...
I've titled this one... "Please,    Take Me With You."        Who wants this one?
(getting a nod from his     wife)    I think we can do something with    that.

I bet you can. I can see it    now -- the lonely little girl,    befriended by empathetic aliens    who teach her how to smile.        It's enough to make you go out and    buy a television.        Next.
You've got to be kidding...
What can I say? I had extra   sauerkraut on my franks that night.
Be that as it may, it's still the   worst piece of garbage I've ever seen.       I'll take it.
Of course you will. You've an   affinity for garbage, don't you?
The picture may be garbage, but the   story... the story will be art.
I don't have a title for it yet...
I'll think of something.
Next order of business, some of    our readers have been writing in    wanting to know what you people    look like.
Write back and tell them we look    like writers. Poor, needy and    incredibly attractive.
The publisher has come up with a    better idea. Mister Stone has    decided to run a picture of you    in next month's issue.
Is this really...
... necessary? I'm afraid so.
Kay... you can sleep late that day.
Of course I can. God forbid that   the public ever finds out K.C.    Hunter is a woman.
I suppose I'm sleeping late that    day, too.
It's not personal, Benny. But as    far as our readers are concerned,    Benny Russell is as white as they    are. Let's just leave it that way.
If the world's not ready for a    woman writer -- imagine what would    happen if it learned about a Negro    with a typewriter -- run for the    hills! It's the end of    civilization!
What about James Baldwin, Richard    Wright, Zora Neal Hurston,    Langston Hughes? Ever heard of    Native Son?
That's literature for liberals and    intellectuals. The average reader    isn't going to spend his hard-earned    cash on stories written by Negroes.
Would someone please shoot me and    put me out of my misery?
How I long for a gun.
I'm sorry, Benny. I wish things    were different, but they're not.
Wishing never changed a damn thing.
Come on, Benny... it's just a    photo.
I'll try to remember that.
You're a dog.
All right, enough standing around.    Get back to work.
What's all the hurry?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: That's my drawing.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Is that so?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Nice suit. Where'd you get it?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I bought it.       Can I have my drawing back?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Hey boy, I'd watch that tone of   voice if I were you.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: What are you doing around here?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I work here.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Where?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: In there.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: What are you -- the janitor?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Awfully well-dressed for a janitor.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: How do we know the picture's yours?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: (struggling to maintain     his composure)    It's a drawing of a space station.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Space station?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Well, get off it.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: See -- it's not worth anything,    except to me.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Let's run him in, check him for    priors.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Nah. We're due uptown in fifteen    minutes.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Take your picture and get out of    here.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: This time, you're getting off with    a warning. Next time, you won't    be so lucky.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: You heard him, move it.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I tell you, Kevin. This city's    going to hell in a handbasket.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Damn shame.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: "And he said to me, 'These words    are trustworthy and true.' And the    Lord, the God of the spirits of    the prophets, has sent his angel    to show his servants what must    soon take place."
"Then the eyes of the blind shall    be opened, and the ears of the    deaf shall be unstopped." Praise    the Lord, open their eyes. Help    them to see.
Are you talking to me?
"Oh, that my words were now    written! Oh, that they were    printed in a book!" Write those    words, Brother Benny. Let them    see the glory of what lies ahead.
How do you know my name?
Go now and write the truth that's    in your heart. The truth "that    shall set them free!"
Praise be the word of the Lord...    Praise to the word of the    prophets. Hallelujah, brothers    and sisters.
Hey, baby. Have a seat. The    usual?
How 'bout scrambling the eggs    today?
My aren't we feeling adventurous.
I just finished the best story    I've ever written.
That's great, baby. I got some    good news, too.
I talked to Mrs. Jackson last    night. She's serious about    retiring in the next couple of    ears. I asked her about selling    this place to us and she said    she'd be willing.
Cassie, we've been over this. I    have a job. I'm a writer.
And how much money have you earned    doing that?
I've only been working at it for    a few years.
A few years? More like    fifteen -- if you count all those    stories you wrote in the Navy.
That was amateur stuff.

Baby, neither one of us is getting    any younger. Don't you see? This    is our chance. we can make some    money. Get married. You're    always writing about the    future -- well, look around -    this is our future.
Hey there, Cassie. Hear the game    last night? I went two for four    and robbed Snider of a tater. You    shoulda heard the crowd -- the way    they were yelling and carrying    on...
Sure they were yelling. They want    to know why the Giants are in    fifth place.
Why don't you tell this fool to    take his business someplace else.
I've thought about it. Trouble    is, if he did leave, he'd take my    heart with him.
Suit yourself. But if you ask me,    you're wasting an awfully pretty    heart.
I don't think so.
Strike three. You're out.
That's all right, I'll get another    turn at bat.        Now how about frying me up some    steak and eggs?
Coming right up. But first, tell    me something -- how come you're    still living uptown? A famous    ballplayer like you can live    anywhere he wants.
The hell I can. They can hardly    get used to me playing alongside    them on the ballfield... living    next to 'em -- that's a whole    other story.
Besides, around here, when people    look at me, it's 'cause they    admire me. There, I'm just a    colored boy who can hit a curve    ball.
Now, if you'll excuse me, my    public awaits.
I'll see to those eggs.
Hey, Benny -- wanna buy a watch?
Where'd you get that?
I found it. Nice, huh?
One of these days, Jimmy, you're    going to find yourself in serious    trouble.
Anything I can get into, I can get    out of.
You keep thinking that -- see what    happens.
Man, how come you're always    lecturing me?
I'm not lecturing you -- I'm    trying to help you.
You want to help me, buy this    watch. I could use the cash.
Why not get a job?
As what -- a delivery boy or a    dishwasher? No, thanks. I like    being my own boss. Setting my own    hours.
Sounds like a great life.
Yours ain't no better. Writing    stories about a bunch of white    people living on the moon. Who    cares about that?
I'm not doing that anymore. I'm    writing about us.
What -- colored people on the moon?
Check out next month's issue.
Colored people on the moon... I    just might do that.
But first, I'm gonna need to raise    me some cash.
She has a worm in her belly?    That's disgusting.        Interesting, but disgusting.
Who... that is, if you don't mind    me asking... are, uh...
I'm Mister Pabst's new secretary.    Darlene Kursky.        Which one of you wrote this?
I did.
You?
Surprise.
It's the best thing I've read    since "The Puppet Masters."    (a beat, almost     apologetic)    I read a lot of science fiction.
Bless you, my child.
The world needs more people like    you.
The story really... I mean to    say... it's quite...
... impressive?
It's a damn fine piece of writing    is what it is. And "Deep Space    Nine" is a very intriguing title.
Very admirable.
The master of understatement.    What he really means is that he    wishes he had half your talent.
I really like this major of    yours... she's a tough cookie.
Science fiction needs more strong    women characters. I'm always    saying that, aren't I, Jules?
Ad nauseam, my dear.
These Cardassians... I like how    you've described them. Their neck    ridges especially. I'll come up    with some sketches to show you.    It could make a nice cover.
Don't waste your time.
You, back to work.
Right away, Mister Pabst.
You too, Roy.
Douglas -- you're not going to    stand there and tell us you don't    like this story.
Oh, I like it all right. It's    good. Very good.
But you know I can't print it.
Why not?
Come on, Benny -- your hero's a    Negro captain. The head of a    space station, for Christ's sake.
What's wrong with that?
People won't accept it. It's not    believable.
And men from Mars are?

Stay out of this, Herb.        Look, Benny, I'm a magazine    editor -- not a crusader. I'm not    here to change the world. I'm    here to put out a magazine.    That's my job. And that means    I've got to answer to Mister    Stone, the national distributors,    the wholesalers --        -- and none of them are going to    want to put this on the newsstand.    For all we know, it could cause    a race riot.
Congratulations, Douglas. That's    the most imbecilic attempt to    rationalize personal cowardice    I've ever heard.
Uh-oh, he's angry now.
Herb's been angry ever since    Joseph Stalin died.
What's that supposed to mean?
You know exactly what it means.
You calling me a red?
Easy.
Calm down, dear boy. We're    writers, not vikings.
I'm not going to let some craven    fascist call me a pinko and get    away with it.
Douglas, what'd you... uh, think    of my story?
I loved it.        You see, Albert's got the right    idea. He's not interested in    Negroes or whites -- he writes    about robots.
That's because he is a robot. No    offense, Albert.
I... uh, like robots. They're    very... efficient.
Here, write me a novella based on    this drawing and I'll print it in    next month's issue. Do a good job    and you might even get the cover.
(holding up his     manuscript)    What about my story?
The way I see it, you can either    burn it or you can put it in a    drawer for fifty years or however    long it takes the human race to    become colorblind.
But I want people to read it now.
Fine. You want me to publish it?    Then make the captain white.
But that's not what I wrote.
It's your call..
I'm sorry they didn't buy your    story, baby. Really I am.
I told you you were wasting your    time.        A colored captain... the only    reason they'll ever let us    space is if they need someone to    shine their shoes. Ain't that    right, Cassie?
I don't know and to be honest, I    don't much care what happens a    hundred years from now. It's    today that matters.
Well I got news for you... today    or a hundred years from now don't    make a bit of difference -- as far    as they're concerned, we'll always    be niggers.
Things are going to change. They    have to.
(not buying it for a     second)    You keep telling yourself that.
Maybe all this is happening for    a reason.
You mean maybe this is God's way    of telling me to quit writing and    go into the restaurant business?

Hey, it's possible.        Baby, I know we could make this    work for us. We could be happy    here. Besides, you don't have to    give up writing altogether...    maybe you could write something    for the Amsterdam News or one of    the other Negro newspapers.
I'm not a reporter. I write    fiction -- and the Amsterdam News    isn't going to publish stories    about a space station four hundred    years in the future.
Hear the game last night?
Hey, I'm sorry -- I didn't mean    to frighten you.
You don't look so good. You sick   or something?
I'm fine.
Want to lie down in the back?
I just need some air.
We still on for tonight?
I'll pick you up around ten.
So what're you doing 'til ten?
Whatever it is, I'm not doing it   with you.
Hello, Brother Benny.
You again? I don't understand...    what do you want from me?
To follow the path of the    Prophets. Walk with the Prophets,    Brother Benny. Show us the way.
What way? I don't know what    you're talking about.
Write the words, Brother Benny.    The words that will lead us out    of the darkness and onto the path    of righteousness.
Write the words, Brother Benny.    Write the words.
Hey, baby. You forgot all about    our date.
Date? Oh, yeah -- that's right.   I'm sorry. I was working...

Ben Sisko? Isn't that your    colored captain?        Why are you writing another one    of those stories? You couldn't    sell the last one. What makes you    think this one will be any    different?
It probably won't be. Doesn't    matter.       It's what I've got to do.
Right now, what you've got to do    is eat.
I'm not hungry.
What time is it anyway?
A little after midnight. I should    be getting home to bed. But    before I go --
-- what do you say we take one    spin around the dance floor.
Feels good, doesn't it?
I could stay like this forever.
Me, too. It's times like these    that I wish we'd never heard of    the Dominion.
scene: 48   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: The Dominion?
scene: 48   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: What do you mean?        You said something about the    Dominion...
What is it, Ben? What's wrong?
scene: 50   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: I don't know -- I think I'm losing   my mind...
scene: 50   INT. DEEP SPACE NINE - SISKO'S QUARTERS

quote: Why? Tell me -- what's wrong?
(knows how odd this     sounds)    I'm starting to see things...    things from my story... it's as    if I'm becoming Captain Sisko.
Baby, you need to get some rest.
It's all right, baby. I'm here.   Just take it easy... I'm with you.
Have you lost your mind?
Lately, I've been asking myself    the same question.

I give you a novella to write -    even offered you a shot at the    cover -- and three weeks later,    instead of a novella, you come    back with six stories -- six    sequels to a story I refused to    publish in the first place. So    I guess the answer to the question    we've both been asking is yes -    you're certifiable!
You might consider printing those    stories yourself -- you know,    through a private publishing    house. A nice, elegant, little    volume. Fifty to a hundred copies.
That's a great idea.
He may as well write them in chalk    on the sidewalk. More people    would read them that way.
You tell him, Kay. I know a good    divorce lawyer if you need one.
I've got an idea. Why not make    it... you know, a dream?
What's that?
Uh... you know, make the ending...    of your first story -- "Deep Space    Nine" -- a dream.
Will that make a difference?
That depends...
On what?
On who's doing the dreaming.
Obviously, someone without much    hope. A shoeshine boy or a    convict -- dreaming of a better    future.
A Negro?
I suppose he'd have to be... if    he's dreaming about a Negro    captain.
Hold on -- making it a dream guts    the whole story.
Shaddup, Herbert.
(disagreeing with     Herbert)    I think it makes it more poignant.
But what about your other Sisko    stories? You can't make them all    dreams.
Let him get the first one    published. He can worry about the    others later.
What do you think, Benny?
I think it's better than chalk on    the sidewalk...
-- bottom of seventh I come up    again. And on an oh-two    fastball -- BAM. Into the    centerfield bleachers. Had to be    at least four hundred feet.
I know all about it, Willie. I    read the newspaper.
Yeah, but you gotta admit -- they    don't tell it as well as I do.
Cassie.
Hey, man. Hear the game last    night? I went two for four.
That's great, Willie. But I just    hit a grand slam.
They're publishing one of my Sisko    stories.        And at three cents a word.
Good for you, baby.
Tonight, we're celebrating.    Dinner, dancing -- the works.
I'll wear my red dress.
You're damn right you will.
My poor feet... baby, you better    marry me soon. I'm not getting    any younger.
But you are getting more and more    beautiful.
Brother Benny.
I was hoping I'd see you again.         I did it. My story's going to be    published.
"The light of the Lord is in his    path." But, this is only the    beginning of your journey -- not    the ending. And the path of the    Prophets sometimes leads into    darkness and pain.
Benny, what's he talking about?         Who are you?
I speak with the voice of the    Prophets.
And in their words, hope and    despair walk arm in arm.
Did you understand any of that?
Is that gunfire?
The time has come, Brother Benny.    Go and "be of good courage."
Jimmy!
Get back.
What happened?
What's it to you?
I know him --
Yeah? Then maybe you can explain    what he was doing trying to break    into that car.
Is that why you shot him? For    breaking into a car?
He had a weapon.
A crowbar?
I said -- stay back!
Stop it! Please!
Don't! You're killing him!
I'm telling you, baby -- you've    been cooped up in this apartment    too long. Going down to the    office will do you good.
I suppose I should be there when    the first copies of this month's    issue are delivered.
Absolutely. After all that work    you did -- you deserve to see your    story in print.        Just no jumping up and down with    excitement -- I wouldn't want you    to hurt yourself.
I'll restrict myself to a proud grin.
You're not having any more of    those... hallucinations, are you?
I'm fine.
Hey, Benny -- long time no see.
Is it here?
Not yet. Pabst is still at the    printers.
But we're all waiting for his    return with baited breath.
We heard... you know, that you    were... ah...
We heard they beat the hell out    of you.
I'm okay.
Glad to see that you're... ah...    you know, up... and about.
Tell him the good news, Albert.
It's... nothing really.
Nothing? He sold a novel to Gnome    Press and he calls it nothing.
A novel -- congratulations!    Robots?
What else?
It's about time.
Hey, Douglas -- where's the    magazine?
There is no magazine. Not this    month anyway. Mister Stone had    the entire run pulped.
He can't do that!
He can and he did. He believes    that this issue quote -- did not    meet our usual high standards --    unquote.
And what's that supposed to mean?
It means he didn't like it.
Which means the public's simply    going to have to get along without    any Incredible Tales this month.
You still haven't said what he    didn't like. The artwork? The    layout? Exactly what "high    standards" is he talking about?
Take it easy, Benny.
It's about my story, isn't it?    That's what this is all about.    He didn't want to publish my    story -- and we all know why.    Because my hero is a colored man.
Hey -- Mister Stone owns this    magazine. If he doesn't want to    publish this month -- we don't    publish this month. End of story.
That doesn't make it right and you    know it.
Don't tell me what I know.    Besides, it's not about what's    right -- it's about what is.
I'm afraid I have some more bad    news, Benny. Mister Stone has    decided your services are no    longer required here.
You're firing me?
I have no choice, Benny. It's his    decision.
Well you can't fire me -- I quit.    To hell with Stone and to hell    with you.
Try to stay calm.
I'm tired of being calm. Calm's    never gotten me a damn thing.
I'm warning you, Benny -- if you    don't stop shouting, I'm calling    the cops.
Call them! Go ahead! They can't    do anything to me. Not anymore.    None of you can.

I'm a human being, dammit! You    can deny me all you want but you    can't deny Ben Sisko. He exists!    That space station -- those    people -- that future -- they    exist!        In here. And in the minds of    everyone of you who read it.
You hear what I'm telling you?    You can pulp the story but you    can't destroy the idea. That    future is real -- I made it real!         You hear me -- it's real!         It's real! It's real!
Rest easy, Brother Benny.
You've walked in the path of the    Prophets. There is no greater    glory.
Tell me, please. Who am I?
Don't you know?
Tell me!
You're the dreamer. And the dream.
Ben!
How long was I out?
Only a few minutes.
Seemed like forever to me.
That's odd. Somehow, your neural   patterns have returned to normal.
That's good, isn't it?
It's very good. I just don't    understand why it happened.
